conventional e+ source on hold so as to
investigate the feasibility of a
polarized positron source for the NLC

undulator and 150 GeV NLC primary

NLC - The Next Linear Collider Project

Production Issues
Production Issues

Collection:
Collection:

Adiabatic Matching Device: different optimization from electron based production due to broader positron spectrum Concerned about beam loading in the initial capture region prior to e+/e- separation because of large particle flux, including the presence of electrons (this is also an issue in the conventional design)
Adiabatic Matching Device: different
optimization from electron based production due
to broader positron spectrum
Concerned about beam loading in the initial
capture region prior to e+/e- separation because of
large particle flux, including the presence of
electrons (this is also an issue in the
conventional design)

Diagnostics:
Diagnostics:

Not much to say; this is more interesting in the case of polarized positron production; bad energy range for polarimetry; very difficuly to test
Not much to say; this is more interesting in the
case of polarized positron production; bad energy
range for polarimetry; very difficuly to test

Overall Proof of Principle:
Overall Proof of Principle:

Every reason to expect the basic e- to g to e+ conversion to work as imagined; polarized e+ production will benefit from a demonstration

Use of a Microundulator to Study Positron Production
Use of a Microundulator to Study Positron Production

We had a discussion at LC02 to explore the possibilities of using a microundulator and the damped, 50 GeV SLAC beam in the FFTB to study positron production. Expectedly warm response from all e+ folks
We had a discussion at LC02 to explore the possibilities of using a
microundulator and the damped, 50 GeV SLAC beam in the FFTB to
study positron production. Expectedly warm response from all e+ folks

An Immodest Proposal
An Immodest Proposal
